Charlotte Coutts /Facebook Charlotte and Dean Coutts say they were harassed by a carpet cleaning company for missing an appointment Charlotte Coutts /Facebook 9 Charlotte had suffered a miscarriage and was in hospital so unable to attend and decided to cancel the appointment

Charlotte and Dean had booked an appointment with Clean Carpets Plymouth back in January. 
But the couple were struck by tragedy when pregnant Charlotte lost her baby and had to be admitted to hospital. 
The pair, who live in Plymouth, said they tried to cancel the booking, but were told by the company they would be charged Â£85 for missing it â€“ and then threatened with having to pay an extra Â£1,000 in â€œadmin feesâ€ for continuing to respond to its text messages. 
Ben has insisted that no invoice was ever issued, despite the couple claiming they were subjected to a string of â€œaggressive messagesâ€ demanding more money. 
The companyâ€™s terms and conditions ask for 48 hoursâ€™ notice but Dean and Charlotte said the circumstances didnâ€™t allow for that. Charlotte Coutts /Facebook 9 Charlotte explained the situation with her miscarriage but it did not stop the company demanding payment 
Ben says if they had known why the couple wanted to cancel, then the situation â€œnever would have happenedâ€. 
He added: â€œWe probably would have sent her a bunch of flowers like we have done in the past. 
â€œI understand some people wouldnâ€™t want to admit to a company they have had a miscarriage, but had she, the situation would have been completely different. 
â€œI accept some responsibility, I do, I really do, but we donâ€™t deserve what has happened to us. The business is gone and we are having to move house.

During a series of texts, the firm, based in the Tavistock area of the city, insisted Charlotte and Dean owed them money â€“ as cancelling an appointment with less than 48 hours notice meant paying an Â£85 fee, as stated in a post pinned to the top of their Facebook page. 
But the couple claimed they were not told of this policy, did not sign any paperwork, and had made and cancelled the appointment within 24 hours â€“ therefore not allowing them to give 48 hoursâ€™ notice. 
When Charlotte, 22, refused to pay and called their behaviour â€œunprofessionalâ€, the company responded in a text message saying: â€œProfessional enough that the rest of your family loved us ğŸ™‚ the terms are there to try and prevent wasted appointments due to last minute cancellationsâ€¦The invoice will be posted later followed by small claims court action :)â€ 
Feeling harassed by their conduct, Charlotte responded: â€œWe have not agreed nothing please stop harassing me. I have recently come out of hospital due to losing my baby I do not need this thank you.â€ (sic) 
Dean, 26, later added: â€œWe never said we wasnâ€™t having it done though. Just not ready after what Charlotte has been throughâ€¦we lost our childâ€¦we donâ€™t have to rearrange.â€ (sic) 
It is claimed Clean Carpets Plymouth then said every time Charlotte sent them a text message they would â€œadd an admin charge of Â£25â€. By the end of the stream of around 30 angry messages, the company claimed the pair owed around Â£1,000 in â€œadmin feesâ€. 
It also made claims its staff had been on the end of â€œthreatening behaviourâ€, allegedly involving members of the coupleâ€™s family.

Vicki added: â€œLosing a baby is tragic, but had we been told from the beginning this was why they couldnâ€™t keep the appointment, it wouldnâ€™t have been a problem.â€ 
It was originally reported that police were investigating claims that the carpet cleaners told Charlotte and Dean: â€œYou deserved to lose your babyâ€. 
Vicki said: â€œI understand it hasnâ€™t been handled very well but we didnâ€™t ever threaten them.â€ 
She continued: â€œItâ€™s horrible to stand there and have your 35-year-old husband beg you to leave him because he feels that he has let me down. That is how it has affected us â€“ and itâ€™s affected our whole family.
